Regional Analysis

East Africa Overtakes Sahel in Youth Uprising Risk

A new report highlights growing frustration among youth due to economic and political grievances.

By Zawadi Intel Staff | Dec 1, 2025

Youth protests are becoming more frequent across East African nations. Â© Zawadi Intel

East Africa has emerged as the new epicenter of youth-led unrest, surpassing the Sahel, which has traditionally been viewed as the most volatile region on the continent.

A recent report highlights democratic backsliding, economic stagnation, and political repression as key drivers of instability across East African states.

Young populations, frustrated by unemployment and inequality, are increasingly turning to protests as a means of expressing discontent.

Analysts argue that the regionâ€™s demographic boom, while a potential asset, has become a liability due to poor governance and limited opportunities.

Comparisons with the Sahel show that while extremist violence dominates headlines there, East Africaâ€™s instability is more rooted in civic and political grievances.

Kenya, Uganda, and Ethiopia have all witnessed waves of demonstrations in recent years, often met with heavy-handed responses from security forces.

Observers warn that repression without reform risks deepening mistrust between governments and their citizens.

Economic inequality remains stark, with urban youth feeling excluded from growth narratives that celebrate infrastructure but neglect job creation.

Rural communities, meanwhile, face land disputes and resource scarcity, adding another layer of tension to the political landscape.

International organizations stress the importance of inclusive governance, urging leaders to prioritize dialogue over confrontation.

Diplomatic efforts are underway to encourage reforms, but progress has been slow and uneven across the region.

Regional bodies such as the African Union and IGAD are being called upon to play a stronger role in mediating disputes and promoting stability.

Global powers, too, have vested interests, with instability in East Africa threatening trade routes and investment flows.

Experts recommend targeted economic reforms, including youth-focused entrepreneurship programs and education initiatives.

Without such measures, the risk of unrest spreading across borders remains high, potentially destabilizing neighboring states.

International aid, while helpful, must be aligned with local realities to avoid fueling dependency or resentment.

Grassroots movements are gaining traction, showing that young people are not only protesting but also organizing for change.

The future of East Africaâ€™s stability hinges on whether governments can harness this energy constructively rather than suppress it.

Ultimately, the region stands at a crossroads: embrace reform and empowerment, or face escalating cycles of unrest that could define the next decade.

Key Takeaways

  • East Africa surpasses the Sahel in youth uprising risk.
  • Key drivers: democratic backsliding and economic stagnation.
  • Youth unemployment and inequality are fueling protests.
  • Experts call for inclusive governance and economic reforms.
